Real Experiences

Expat Stories

No BS. Real stories from people actually living here - the good, the bad, and the "why didn't anyone tell me this before I moved?"

Jake Donovan
Portland, Oregon, USA ‚Ä¢ Software Developer
12 min read
Palermo Soho2 years in BANear Plaza Serrano
"I came for three months and stayed for two years. The first month I was like 'what the hell is a blue dollar?' Now I can explain it to newcomers in my sleep."

Jake arrived as a digital nomad in 2022, thinking he'd bounce around South America. Two years later, he's still in the same apartment on Costa Rica Street, has a local girlfriend, and has learned that 'ma√±ana' doesn't always mean tomorrow.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ I can actually afford to live alone in a nice apartment
  • ‚Ä¢ The tech community here is surprisingly tight-knit
  • ‚Ä¢ Nobody judges you for having wine with lunch
  • ‚Ä¢ La Viruta on Wednesday nights - life-changing
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The garant√≠a system is actual hell. I needed a local friend to co-sign for my apartment
  • ‚Ä¢ Inflation means you're constantly doing mental math
  • ‚Ä¢ Good luck getting anything done between 1-4pm
The Reality

You will gain weight. The food is incredible and cheap. The gym culture exists but it's not the same pressure as the US. I've accepted my 'empanada body'.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíBring more cash than you think. The blue dollar rate is real and it matters.
  • ‚ÜíLearn Spanish BEFORE you come. 'I can learn there' is a cute idea that will make your first 6 months harder.
  • ‚ÜíThe European architecture tricks you. This is still Latin America. Things break. Plans change.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$650 USD (2BR in Palermo Soho, splitting with girlfriend)
Utilities:$40 USD (varies wildly with inflation)
Food:$400 USD (eating out 3-4x/week)
Coworking:$120 USD (WeWork membership)
Transport:$30 USD (SUBE card + occasional Ubers)
Total:~$1,240/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçLa Biela in Recoleta for coffee and people-watching
  • üìçMercado de San Telmo on Sundays (get the chorip√°n)
  • üìçEl Boliche de Dario for the best empanadas
  • üìçAny park with mate and friends on weekends

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I tried to open a bank account in my first month. Don't. Just use Western Union, bring cash, or use crypto. The banking system here is not designed for you and you don't need it anyway.

Remote tech work from cafesTango lessons at La VirutaWeekend trips to TigreBuilding a local friend group
Klaus & Ingrid Hoffmann
Munich, Germany ‚Ä¢ Retired Engineer & Teacher
15 min read
Recoleta3 years in BAAvenida Callao near Recoleta Cemetery
"Our German pension gives us a lifestyle here we could never afford in Munich. But the healthcare system took us a year to figure out."

Klaus and Ingrid moved to Buenos Aires at 68 and 65, chasing better weather and lower costs. They've navigated the healthcare maze, dealt with a broken hip, and learned that Argentine dinner time is non-negotiable.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ Our apartment has a terrace with a view. In Munich, we'd be in a studio.
  • ‚Ä¢ The private healthcare (OSDE) is excellent and affordable
  • ‚Ä¢ The cafe culture suits us perfectly
  • ‚Ä¢ We've made more friends here in 3 years than 20 in Munich
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The garant√≠a was impossible. We had to pay 6 months upfront
  • ‚Ä¢ Paperwork. So much paperwork. Everything requires a DNI
  • ‚Ä¢ When Ingrid broke her hip, navigating the hospital system in Spanish was terrifying
The Reality

You will eat dinner at 10pm. There is no alternative. We tried to find restaurants that opened at 7pm. They don't exist or they're tourist traps. We adapted. Now we have 'merienda' at 5pm like locals.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíGet a good immigration lawyer. The retirement visa process is straightforward but the bureaucracy is not.
  • ‚ÜíBring original birth certificates, marriage certificates, everything. Apostilled.
  • ‚ÜíThe 'European feel' is only skin deep. Underneath, this is a different world.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$900 USD (2BR with terrace, full service)
Utilities:$60 USD
Food:$500 USD (mostly cooking, nice dinners out)
Healthcare:$300 USD (OSDE 310 plan for both)
Transport:$100 USD (mostly taxis - we're not taking the subway at our age)
Total:~$1,860/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçLa Biela for coffee and pastries
  • üìçThe parks in Palermo for walking
  • üìçTeatro Col√≥n for opera and concerts
  • üìçOur building's terrace with wine and neighbors

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

We didn't realize how important the DNI is. We tried to do everything with our passport for the first 6 months. Get your temporary residency started immediately, then get your DNI. Everything is easier with a DNI.

Retirement visa processHealthcare qualityBuilding social life in 60sCost of living comparison
Marisol Vega
Miami, USA (Cuban-American) ‚Ä¢ Marketing Manager
11 min read
Belgrano1.5 years in BACalle Echeverr√≠a near Chinatown
"I moved here with my Argentine boyfriend. Being Latina, I thought I'd adapt easily. I was wrong. Miami Cuban is not the same as Porte√±o."

Marisol followed her boyfriend home after 3 years of long-distance. She thought her Spanish and Latin background would make it easy. Instead, she struggled with the 'Porte√±o' attitude, the economic uncertainty, and finding work.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ Living with my partner finally, after years of long-distance
  • ‚Ä¢ The food reminds me of my abuela's cooking sometimes
  • ‚Ä¢ Weekend asados with his family are everything
  • ‚Ä¢ I found a remote job with a US company - game changer
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The 'Porte√±o' superiority complex is real. They think they're the Europeans of South America
  • ‚Ä¢ Finding a job that pays in dollars took 8 months
  • ‚Ä¢ His family still asks when we're having kids. Every. Sunday.
The Reality

The inflation is psychological warfare. You never know what anything costs. You develop this hoarding instinct - buy it now because it'll be more expensive tomorrow. I have 6 bottles of my favorite shampoo.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíYour Spanish being 'good' isn't enough. Porte√±o slang is its own language.
  • ‚ÜíThe job market is brutal if you need pesos. Start looking for remote work before you move.
  • ‚ÜíDating a local helps but also complicates everything. You're not just dating him, you're dating his entire family.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$0 (living with partner, he owns the apartment)
Utilities:$50 USD (my contribution)
Food:$300 USD (my share of groceries and eating out)
Therapy:$200 USD (yes, really, everyone has a therapist here)
Transport:$40 USD
Total:~$590/month (lucky situation)

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçBarrio Chino for Asian groceries and bubble tea
  • üìçLas Ca√±itas for drinks with other expat friends
  • üìçMy boyfriend's family house in Olivos for Sunday asado
  • üìçAny feria artesanal for shopping

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I thought I could just 'find a local job.' I applied to 40+ positions. The salaries were insulting - like $800 USD/month for a senior marketing role. I finally got a remote US job and now I live like a queen here. Don't move without dollar income.

Moving with a local partnerJob search realityCultural adaptationRemote work transition
Tom Brennan
Dublin, Ireland ‚Ä¢ UX Designer
10 min read
Villa Crespo8 months in BAMalabia near the outlet shops
"The 'ma√±ana' culture nearly broke me. I'm Irish, we're direct, we get things done. Here, everything is 'tranqui' until it's an emergency."

Tom moved to Buenos Aires thinking he'd found the perfect remote work setup. Instead, he spent his first three months in a Kafkaesque nightmare of delayed deliveries, missed appointments, and learning that 'yes' often means 'maybe' or even 'no.'

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The cost of living is absurdly good for someone with European salary
  • ‚Ä¢ The steak. My god, the steak.
  • ‚Ä¢ Once you make friends, they're friends for life
  • ‚Ä¢ The city is beautiful in a way that still makes me stop and stare
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The internet went out for 3 days and my landlord said 'tranqui, it'll be fixed when it's fixed'
  • ‚Ä¢ Delivery times are fictional. 'It arrives Tuesday' means 'sometime this month hopefully'
  • ‚Ä¢ Nobody tells you no directly. You have to learn to read between the lines
The Reality

I had to learn to lower my expectations. Things that would take a day in Dublin take a week here. Things that would take a week take a month. You either adapt or you go insane. I'm still working on the adaptation.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíBring a VPN that works. The internet restrictions here are annoying.
  • ‚ÜíGet a local SIM immediately. WhatsApp is the operating system of Argentina.
  • ‚ÜíDon't expect things to work the way they do at home. They don't. They won't.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$550 USD (studio in Villa Crespo)
Utilities:$35 USD
Food:$350 USD (cooking mostly, steak splurges)
Coworking:$80 USD (local coworking space)
Therapy:$150 USD (I need it here)
Transport:$25 USD
Total:~$1,190/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçThe Irish pubs when I need to hear English and feel at home
  • üìçDon Julio when someone else is paying
  • üìçMy rooftop for mate and complaining with other expats
  • üìçPalermo parks for running and clearing my head

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I signed a lease without understanding the garant√≠a system. I thought my Irish bank references would work. They didn't. I had to pay a 'guarantor service' $500 to basically vouch for me. Read about this stuff BEFORE you sign anything.

Remote work challengesCultural adjustmentMa√±ana culture navigationBuilding patience
Priya Sharma
London, UK ‚Ä¢ Freelance Writer
9 min read
San Telmo6 months in BADefensa near Plaza Dorrego
"I came to write a novel. Instead, I'm writing about inflation and economic collapse. The irony isn't lost on me."

Priya moved to Buenos Aires for inspiration and affordable living as a writer. She found both, but also found herself navigating an economy in crisis, learning to think in multiple currencies, and discovering that artistic inspiration sometimes comes from chaos.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ I can afford to write full-time here. In London, I needed a day job.
  • ‚Ä¢ San Telmo is like living in a movie. The tango, the street art, the antique shops
  • ‚Ä¢ The literary scene here is incredible - bookstores everywhere
  • ‚Ä¢ I've written more in 6 months than in 2 years in London
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ Watching prices change weekly is anxiety-inducing
  • ‚Ä¢ I had to become an amateur economist just to grocery shop
  • ‚Ä¢ The power went out during a deadline. 'Tranqui' doesn't pay my bills
The Reality

You become obsessed with exchange rates. You check the blue dollar rate like other people check Instagram. You know which cuevas give the best rates. You have opinions about stablecoins. This is not normal life.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíHave multiple income streams in different currencies. Peso income is worthless.
  • ‚ÜíThe romantic idea of the struggling artist is cute until you're actually struggling.
  • ‚ÜíBring a power bank and download offline maps. Infrastructure fails.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$400 USD (room in shared apartment, San Telmo)
Utilities:$25 USD
Food:$250 USD (cooking, cheap empanadas, occasional splurge)
Coworking:$0 (writing in cafes)
Transport:$20 USD
Misc:$100 USD
Total:~$795/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçEl Federal for writing and coffee
  • üìçMercado de San Telmo for cheap lunches
  • üìçThe feria on Sundays for people-watching
  • üìçAny quiet corner of a milonga for tango inspiration

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I didn't bring enough cash and I didn't understand the blue dollar. I was using my UK card at the official rate for my first month. I basically paid double for everything. Learn about the parallel exchange rates BEFORE you spend a penny.

Living on freelance incomeCreative inspirationEconomic realitySan Telmo life
Sofia Nguyen
Sydney, Australia ‚Ä¢ Freelance Graphic Designer
12 min read
Villa Crespo1.5 years in BACalle Loyola near Parque Centenario
"I sold everything in Sydney, bought a one-way ticket, and landed with two suitcases and a Wacom tablet. Best financial decision I ever made. My rent here is less than my weekly coffee budget back home."

Sofia left Australia's eye-watering cost of living at 27, drawn by Buenos Aires' street art scene and the promise of stretching her freelance income. She found a creative community she never expected, learned to love fernet con coca, and accidentally became the go-to designer for half the expat businesses in Villa Crespo.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ My apartment has 3-meter ceilings, exposed brick, and a balcony. In Sydney I was renting a shoebox in Marrickville for triple the price
  • ‚Ä¢ The street art here is museum-quality. Every walk to the grocery store is an art gallery
  • ‚Ä¢ Villa Crespo has this incredible mix of old-school porte√±o culture and new creative energy
  • ‚Ä¢ The cafe culture is perfect for freelancers - nobody rushes you out after one coffee
  • ‚Ä¢ I've connected with more designers and illustrators here than I did in 5 years in Sydney
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The internet quality is inconsistent. I've lost video calls mid-presentation with clients
  • ‚Ä¢ Getting paid from Australian clients involves three different apps and losing 4-5% in transfer fees
  • ‚Ä¢ The summer heat in January/February is brutal - my apartment turns into an oven and AC units are expensive to run
The Reality

You will become a different kind of creative here. The chaos, the color, the intensity of this city seeps into your work. My portfolio has completely transformed - it's bolder, more expressive, more alive. But you also learn that 'creative inspiration' doesn't pay the bills when your internet drops during a client deadline at 2am because of a power cut in your building.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíSet up Wise (formerly TransferWise) and a crypto wallet before you leave. You need multiple ways to move money.
  • ‚ÜíBring your own tech. Laptops and tablets cost 2-3x more here due to import taxes. My backup Wacom would have cost me $800 USD locally.
  • ‚ÜíThe Australian-to-Argentine culture shock is real. We're both 'relaxed' cultures but in completely different ways. Argentine 'relaxed' means your plumber might show up... eventually.
  • ‚ÜíJoin the BA Creatives WhatsApp group immediately. It's how you find clients, collaborators, and sanity.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$450 USD (1BR in Villa Crespo, beautiful old building)
Utilities:$45 USD (including internet - Fibertel 300mb)
Food:$280 USD (cooking a lot, ferias for produce, occasional Restaurant Animo splurge)
Coworking:$70 USD (Selina coworking days when I need fast WiFi)
Transport:$25 USD (I bike everywhere, SUBE for rainy days)
Misc:$80 USD (art supplies, Procreate subscription, life)
Total:~$950/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçCaf√© Registrado on Humberto Primo for the best specialty coffee in the city
  • üìçParque Centenario weekend feria for vintage finds and people sketching
  • üìçGaler√≠a Patio del Liceo for art exhibitions and creative meetups
  • üìçCervecer√≠a On Tap in Villa Crespo for craft beer with other freelancers
  • üìçHollywood in Cambodia bar for late-night cocktails and live music

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I didn't get a monotributo (tax ID) for my first 8 months. I was just receiving money through Western Union and crypto like a tourist. Then I wanted to sign a proper lease and they asked for proof of income. No monotributo, no lease. Getting it set up took 2 months of bureaucratic hell with a contador. Do this early, even if you're freelancing for overseas clients.

Freelance life on a budgetCreative community buildingStreet art cultureAustralian expat perspective
Marcus Williams
London, United Kingdom ‚Ä¢ Retired Financial Analyst
14 min read
Belgrano4 years in BAAvenida Cabildo near Barrancas de Belgrano
"My City pension in London bought me a modest flat and careful budgeting. Here, my wife and I live in a three-bedroom apartment with a doorman, eat at excellent restaurants twice a week, and still save money. The maths simply works."

Marcus and his wife Patricia retired from London at 63 and 60, after Marcus spent 35 years in the City. They chose Buenos Aires over the traditional British expat destinations after a two-week scouting trip. Four years on, they've built a rich social life around tango, Teatro Col√≥n season tickets, and a circle of Argentine and expat friends who've become family.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The cultural life is extraordinary. Teatro Col√≥n alone is worth moving here - world-class opera for the price of a London cinema ticket
  • ‚Ä¢ Belgrano feels like a leafy European suburb. Barrancas de Belgrano park is our daily walk and it's genuinely beautiful
  • ‚Ä¢ We've taken up tango properly. At our age! Patricia is obsessed. We go to milongas three nights a week
  • ‚Ä¢ The private healthcare through Swiss Medical is superb. Marcus had a knee replacement last year - the surgeon trained at Johns Hopkins and the total cost was a fraction of private UK care
  • ‚Ä¢ Argentines genuinely respect older people. We're not invisible here the way seniors become in London
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The bureaucracy is Dickensian. Renewing our temporary residency involved 14 separate documents, three office visits, and a notarized translation of our marriage certificate
  • ‚Ä¢ We miss Marks & Spencer, proper cheddar, and reliable public transport that runs on time
  • ‚Ä¢ The economic instability is wearing. We've lived through three currency crises in four years. You learn to keep most of your money offshore
The Reality

At our age, healthcare is everything. We pay $520 USD a month for Swiss Medical's top plan covering both of us, and the quality is genuinely excellent. But navigating the system requires Spanish. We hired a health advocate - essentially a bilingual person who helps you deal with the medical bureaucracy. Best $100/month we spend. Without her, Patricia's cataract surgery would have been a nightmare.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíGet the retirement visa (pensionado) sorted before you arrive. You need proof of pension income - minimum around $500 USD/month. Our immigration lawyer, Dr. Gabriela Montoya, was worth every peso.
  • ‚ÜíOpen a dollar account at ICBC or Santander once you have your DNI. It lets you receive international transfers without the blue dollar headache.
  • ‚ÜíLearn conversational Spanish to B1 level minimum before moving. At our age, immersion learning is slower. We did six months of intensive classes before leaving London.
  • ‚ÜíBring your complete medical records translated into Spanish. Every specialist wants your full history.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$950 USD (3BR in Belgrano, portero building, near Cabildo subway)
Utilities:$80 USD (including cable, internet, building expenses)
Food:$450 USD (good groceries, restaurants twice weekly, wine)
Healthcare:$520 USD (Swiss Medical Plan SMG30 for two)
Transport:$120 USD (taxis mostly, SUBE for short trips)
Misc:$150 USD (Teatro Col√≥n, tango, social activities)
Total:~$2,270/month for two

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçBarrancas de Belgrano park for morning walks and weekend book fairs
  • üìçTeatro Col√≥n - we have season tickets, absolutely non-negotiable
  • üìçLa C√°tedra Tango in Almagro for milongas on Tuesday and Thursday nights
  • üìçEl Preferido de Palermo for classic Argentine lunch with friends
  • üìçThe British Argentine community at St. Andrew's Scots Church events

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

We brought too many belongings in a shipping container. The customs process took four months, cost $3,000 in storage and brokerage fees, and half the things we shipped we never use. Sell everything. Bring two suitcases each and buy what you need here. Furniture is cheap and the apartment came partly furnished anyway.

Retirement visa processHealthcare comparisonTango lifestyleCouple's adaptationCultural immersion after 60
Ana & Carlos Ferreira
S√£o Paulo, Brazil ‚Ä¢ Restaurant Owners
15 min read
San Telmo5 years in BACalle Chile near Parque Lezama
"In S√£o Paulo we worked 16-hour days and could barely afford rent. Here we own a restaurant, live above it, and our kids play in the park across the street. The Mercosur visa made it possible - two Brazilians could never have done this in Europe or the US."

Ana and Carlos left Brazil's restaurant industry after a decade of grinding. The Mercosur residency agreement let them settle legally in Argentina within months. They opened 'Boteco Lezama' - a Brazilian-Argentine fusion spot in San Telmo that's become a neighborhood institution. Five years in, they employ eight people and have permanent residency.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The Mercosur visa path is incredible. We had temporary residency in 90 days. Try doing that in the US or Europe as restaurant workers
  • ‚Ä¢ Commercial rent in San Telmo was a quarter of what we'd pay for the same space in Vila Madalena back home
  • ‚Ä¢ Argentines love Brazilian food. Coxinhas, p√£o de queijo, feijoada - they go crazy for it
  • ‚Ä¢ The neighborhood has embraced us. Our regulars are like family now
  • ‚Ä¢ Our kids go to a public school two blocks away and they're thriving - fully bilingual in Spanish and Portuguese
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The AFIP (tax authority) is relentless. The tax system for small businesses is complicated and changes constantly. Our contador earns every peso
  • ‚Ä¢ Supplier prices change weekly. We've had to reprint our menu four times this year alone
  • ‚Ä¢ The habilitaci√≥n (business permit) process took 11 months. Eleven. We operated in legal limbo the entire time
  • ‚Ä¢ Importing Brazilian ingredients is nearly impossible. We source locally and adapt recipes
The Reality

Running a restaurant in Argentina means you're also an amateur economist, a tax strategist, and a crisis manager. When the peso crashed in 2024, our ingredient costs doubled overnight but we couldn't raise prices that fast or we'd lose customers. You learn to build fat margins on some items to survive the shocks on others. Feijoada is our loss leader. Caipirinhas are where we make the money.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíRegister as a Sociedad de Responsabilidad Limitada (SRL) from day one. We started as monotributistas and the transition was a bureaucratic nightmare.
  • ‚ÜíThe Mercosur visa is easy but you still need patience. Bring every document apostilled and translated by a traductor p√∫blico.
  • ‚ÜíFind a good contador BEFORE you open the business. Ours, Mart√≠n, literally saved us from a tax audit that would have shut us down in year two.
  • ‚ÜíLocation matters more than concept. San Telmo foot traffic on weekends saved us during slow months.
  • ‚ÜíBuild relationships with multiple suppliers. When one can't deliver (which happens constantly), you need backups.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$1,100 USD (combined: restaurant space + 2BR apartment above, San Telmo)
Utilities:$180 USD (restaurant + apartment, gas-heavy for commercial kitchen)
Food:$800 USD (family of 4 groceries + some restaurant inventory overlap)
Transport:$60 USD (mostly walking, delivery moto for catering)
Misc:$350 USD (kids' school supplies, activities, personal expenses)
Total:~$2,490/month personal + ~$500 additional business costs

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçParque Lezama every evening with the kids and other neighborhood families
  • üìçMercado de San Telmo for sourcing and morning coffee at Coffee Town
  • üìçThe Brazilian expat asado meetups in Costanera Sur once a month
  • üìçFeria de San Telmo on Sundays - we sometimes set up a coxinha stand for extra income
  • üìçBar Plaza Dorrego for a late-night fernet after closing the restaurant

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

We underestimated working capital. We budgeted for renovations and first month's rent but didn't account for the habilitaci√≥n delays, slow first months, and the gap between spending on ingredients and actually getting paid. We nearly went broke in month four. Bring at least six months of living expenses PLUS your business startup costs. And then add 30% more.

Mercosur visa advantagesOpening a business in ArgentinaBrazilian-Argentine cultural bridgeFamily relocationRestaurant economics in inflation
Yuki Tanaka
Tokyo, Japan ‚Ä¢ Language Teacher
11 min read
Almagro8 months in BACalle Medrano near Parque Rivadavia
"In Tokyo, I was a salaryman working 70-hour weeks. Here, I teach Japanese four hours a day and spend the rest exploring, studying Spanish, and actually living. My salary is tiny but my life is enormous."

Yuki left a burnout-inducing corporate job in Tokyo at 31 to teach Japanese abroad. He chose Buenos Aires partly because of the small but passionate Japanese-Argentine community, and partly because it was the furthest he could get from his old life. Eight months in, his Spanish is shaky, his budget is tight, but he's never been happier.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The work-life balance is unrecognizable compared to Japan. People here actually prioritize living over working
  • ‚Ä¢ There's a surprising Japanese-Argentine community - the Jard√≠n Japon√©s in Palermo hosts cultural events and I teach there sometimes
  • ‚Ä¢ Argentines are incredibly warm. Random strangers invite you to asados. In Tokyo, my neighbors of 5 years never spoke to me
  • ‚Ä¢ Almagro is genuine Buenos Aires - no tourists, real neighborhood life, the best pizza at El Noble and G√ºerr√≠n nearby
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The bureaucracy makes Japanese bureaucracy look efficient, and that's saying something. Getting my DNI took 5 months of Kafkaesque appointments
  • ‚Ä¢ Personal space doesn't exist here. People stand close, kiss you on the cheek the first time they meet you. I had to recalibrate everything
  • ‚Ä¢ The noise. My building has no sound insulation. I can hear my neighbor's entire telenovela. In Tokyo, silence was sacred
The Reality

Teaching Japanese in Buenos Aires pays very little in global terms - about $8-12 USD per hour for private lessons. I survive because my costs are so low. But you have to be comfortable with financial uncertainty. I budget meticulously, something my Japanese upbringing prepared me for perfectly. I track every expense in a kakeibo (Japanese budget journal). Most months I break even. Some months I dip into savings. It's the opposite of financial security, but it's also the opposite of spiritual bankruptcy.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíStart finding students BEFORE you arrive. Post on Buenos Aires language exchange Facebook groups and italki. I had three students lined up before landing.
  • ‚ÜíThe Japanese-Argentine community (Nikkei) is small but incredibly welcoming. Connect with the Asociaci√≥n Japonesa en la Argentina - they helped me find housing and students.
  • ‚ÜíWhatsApp is life here. In Japan we use LINE. Here, if you're not on WhatsApp, you don't exist. All my students book through WhatsApp.
  • ‚ÜíLearn to say 'no' to social invitations or you'll never have free time. Argentines will invite you to something every single night.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$320 USD (room in shared apartment with two Argentine roommates, Almagro)
Utilities:$30 USD (my share)
Food:$200 USD (cooking Japanese food with local ingredients, ferias for vegetables)
Transport:$20 USD (subte and walking)
Misc:$80 USD (teaching materials, Spanish classes at CUI, phone)
Total:~$650/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçJard√≠n Japon√©s in Palermo for cultural events and a taste of home
  • üìçParque Rivadavia weekend book market - I'm building a Spanish library slowly
  • üìçCUI (Centro Universitario de Idiomas) where I take Spanish classes
  • üìçThe language exchange meetups at Mundolingo in Palermo every Wednesday
  • üìçMy kitchen, teaching my roommates to make onigiri while they teach me empanada folding

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I tried to find an apartment on my own without speaking Spanish, without a DNI, and without understanding garant√≠as. I spent two weeks in a terrible hostel in Once, panicking. Then a contact from the Asociaci√≥n Japonesa connected me with my current roommates who were looking for a third person. The lesson: use community networks. Trying to navigate Buenos Aires housing alone, especially without Spanish, is a recipe for misery and getting scammed.

Career change abroadJapanese-Argentine cultural exchangeMinimalist budget livingLanguage learning journeyWork-life balance transformation
Sarah & Tom Mitchell
Vancouver, Canada ‚Ä¢ Parents & Remote Workers (UX Researcher & DevOps Engineer)
14 min read
N√∫√±ez2 years in BANear Avenida del Libertador and the river
"We were spending $6,000 a month just on childcare and mortgage in Vancouver. Here, our kids go to an excellent bilingual school, we have a live-in nanny two days a week, and we're saving more than we ever did in Canada. The tradeoff? Explaining to our parents why we moved our grandchildren to South America."

Sarah and Tom relocated with their two kids - Emma (9) and Liam (6) - after realizing remote work meant they didn't have to endure Vancouver's cost of living anymore. They chose N√∫√±ez for its quiet, family-friendly streets near the river, the proximity to international schools, and the fact that it feels like a small town inside a massive city.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ Lincoln International School is genuinely excellent. Bilingual curriculum, small classes, and our kids are now fluent in Spanish
  • ‚Ä¢ The family culture here is incredible. Kids are welcome everywhere, even at 10pm restaurants. No dirty looks for bringing children to a nice dinner
  • ‚Ä¢ Costanera Norte is our backyard - running paths, playgrounds, weekend cycling along the river
  • ‚Ä¢ Our kids have more independence here than they ever would in Vancouver. Emma walks to her friend's house three blocks away. In Vancouver we drove her everywhere
  • ‚Ä¢ We found an amazing pediatrician through Swiss Medical who does house calls. House calls! For $15 USD
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ The school costs $800 USD/month per kid. It's the biggest expense by far and non-negotiable for us
  • ‚Ä¢ Birthday parties here are a production. Every weekend is another party with a rented salon, magician, and 40 kids. The social pressure to keep up is exhausting
  • ‚Ä¢ Getting the kids' Canadian school records recognized took three months of apostilles and translations
  • ‚Ä¢ Argentine grandparents spoil the neighborhood kids rotten. Our kids now expect dulce de leche with every meal
The Reality

Moving with kids is a different game entirely. You're not just adapting yourself - you're watching your children adapt, and that's both beautiful and heartbreaking. Emma cried every day for the first month. She missed her friends, her teacher, her room. Then one day she came home speaking Spanish with an Argentine accent and asked if her Vancouver friend could come visit. Liam adapted in about three days because six-year-olds are basically invincible. The school community became our social network - other international families who understood exactly what we were going through.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíApply to international schools 6 months before moving. Lincoln, Northlands, and St. Andrew's all have waitlists. We got lucky with a mid-year opening.
  • ‚ÜíBring your kids' vaccination records translated and apostilled. Argentine schools require specific vaccines on a different schedule than Canada.
  • ‚ÜíJoin the BA Families expat Facebook group immediately. It's the single most useful resource for parents - school reviews, pediatrician recommendations, playdate connections.
  • ‚ÜíBudget for activities. Swimming, football, art classes - kids need structure and friends. Budget $150-200 per kid per month for extracurriculars.
  • ‚ÜíYour kids will adapt faster than you. Let them lead sometimes. Liam taught us more about the neighborhood than Google Maps ever did.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$1,200 USD (3BR house with small garden, N√∫√±ez, near the school)
Utilities:$100 USD (including high-speed internet - essential for remote work)
Food:$600 USD (family of 4, cooking mostly, kids eat everything)
Healthcare:$400 USD (Swiss Medical family plan, all 4 of us)
Transport:$80 USD (car service for school runs, SUBE for city trips)
Misc:$1,100 USD (school $1,600 for two, activities $350, split across months)
Total:~$3,480/month for family of 4

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçCostanera Norte bike path every weekend with the kids
  • üìçParque de la Memoria playground - best river views in the city
  • üìçClub Obras for kids' swimming lessons and Saturday morning sports
  • üìçCaminito in La Boca for art days with Emma (she's obsessed with the colors)
  • üìçSunday asados with other international school families - rotating houses

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

We assumed our Canadian health insurance would cover us internationally for the first few months. It didn't, not meaningfully. Liam got a nasty ear infection in week two and we paid out of pocket at a private clinic - $400 for the visit and antibiotics. We signed up for Swiss Medical the next day. Get health coverage sorted BEFORE you arrive, not after your kid spikes a fever at midnight in a country where you don't speak the language yet.

International school experienceFamily relocation logisticsKids' adaptationRemote work with kidsHealthcare for families
Diego Morales
Mexico City, Mexico ‚Ä¢ Digital Marketing Consultant
13 min read
Palermo Hollywood3 years in BACalle Honduras near the production studios
"Everyone thinks being Mexican in Argentina is easy because we speak the same language. We don't. They speak something else entirely. But once you crack the code, being a Spanish-speaker here is an enormous advantage over English-speaking expats."

Diego moved from Mexico City's startup scene to Buenos Aires to tap into the growing LATAM tech market while enjoying a lower cost of living. Three years later, he runs a small consultancy serving clients across Latin America, has an Argentine partner, and has strong opinions about why Buenos Aires' tacos are a crime against humanity but the nightlife makes up for it.

The Good
  • ‚Ä¢ The LATAM tech and startup scene here is booming. Buenos Aires is basically the Silicon Valley of South America and I landed right in the middle of it
  • ‚Ä¢ Being a native Spanish speaker means you skip the hardest part of expat life. I was functional from day one - banks, leases, doctors, everything
  • ‚Ä¢ Palermo Hollywood is creative energy incarnate. Production companies, tech startups, design studios, ad agencies - all my potential clients are within walking distance
  • ‚Ä¢ The nightlife is genuinely world-class. Mexico City is good but Buenos Aires at 3am on a Saturday is another dimension
  • ‚Ä¢ The work-life balance - Argentines taught me that working until midnight isn't a badge of honor, it's a failure of planning
The Bad
  • ‚Ä¢ Rioplatense Spanish is a trip. 'Vos' instead of 't√∫', 'che' every other word, and they pronounce 'll' as 'sh'. I sounded like a tourist for months despite being Mexican
  • ‚Ä¢ Argentine clients pay late. Always. Mexican business culture has its issues but at least people pay on the agreed date. Here, 30 days means 60, and 60 means maybe
  • ‚Ä¢ I miss real Mexican food desperately. There are Mexican restaurants here but they're... an interpretation. The salsa is sweet. The tortillas are wrong. I've started making my own
The Reality

The biggest advantage of being a Latin American expat here versus a North American or European one is that you understand the underlying logic. The bureaucracy, the improvisation, the 'it'll work out' mentality - it's familiar. You don't waste energy being shocked by it. What catches you off guard is the Argentine ego. They genuinely believe Buenos Aires is the Paris of South America and they'll argue about it passionately. Once you stop fighting it and start appreciating it, you realize they're not entirely wrong.

What I Wish I Knew Before Moving

  • ‚ÜíGet a CUIL/CUIT immediately. As a LATAM professional, you can register as monotributista relatively easily and invoice Argentine clients legally. It opens doors.
  • ‚ÜíThe Mercosur residency path exists for Mexicans too through bilateral agreements, but it's slower than for Brazilians. Budget 6-8 months for temporary residency.
  • ‚ÜíBuild your network at Palermo tech meetups and WeWork events before you need clients. The Argentine business world runs on personal connections even more than Mexico's does.
  • ‚ÜíKeep your Mexican clients. The time zone overlap with Mexico is perfect (same zone) and peso-denominated Argentine income alone won't sustain you.
  • ‚ÜíLearn the local slang fast. 'Boludo', 'quilombo', 'al pedo', 'fiaca' - these aren't in any textbook but they're in every conversation.

My Monthly Budget (USD)

Rent:$600 USD (1BR in Palermo Hollywood, modern building with amenities)
Utilities:$50 USD (including 100mb fiber)
Food:$300 USD (cooking Mexican food at home, eating out 2-3x week)
Coworking:$90 USD (WeWork hot desk, essential for networking)
Transport:$35 USD (mostly walking and subte, occasional Uber for client meetings)
Misc:$75 USD (nightlife, gym at Megatlon, imported hot sauce habit)
Total:~$1,150/month

Where I Hang Out

  • üìçWeWork Palermo Hollywood for work and accidentally running into future clients
  • üìçNicky Harrison speakeasy for Thursday night cocktails with the marketing crowd
  • üìçParque Las Heras for Saturday morning runs and outdoor gym sessions
  • üìçLa F√°brica del Taco - the closest thing to real Mexican food (I've trained the chef personally)
  • üìçCongo bar on Honduras for when you want to dance until the sun comes up

My Biggest Mistake (So You Don't Make It)

I quoted my first Argentine client in dollars. Big mistake. They agreed, then the peso crashed, and suddenly my invoice was 'too expensive' even though the number hadn't changed. Now I quote in dollars but offer a peso payment option at a fixed rate with a one-week payment window. It sounds complicated but it saved every client relationship I have. Learn to be creative with pricing or you'll lose Argentine clients every time there's a devaluation, which is roughly every Tuesday.
